instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has green light, no fan spin and no power (consumes 40 mA on PS).

I realize that the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> was burnt (with pad 8 blown without pad), <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> burnt without both pads,  <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> burnt without pad 1, and i think that this is the cause of the behaviour.

I try to scratch the pads to make some jumpers, but i cant find the tracks., and it seems that it will be very hard to "reconstruct" some of those signals.

How can i make some jumpers (from where; i think that i need to make the jumper before the sgnal arrives to the pad, and not when it parts away from the pad), to bring signal to the missing pads? Is this approach the best approach?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Forget the cap, rebuild trace pad 8 only.
Easy job, I usually use 0.03 mm enamelled wire.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi, thanks for the reply.

should i make a jumper from <RESISTOR>R8131</RESISTOR> to <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>? And what about <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> (itÂ´s also missing?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
You have <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> trace 2-3mm away from pin 8; look at a good board.
Replace <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>, of course.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Sorry to be so annoying. but I'm not understanding.

I believe that you are referring to the trace between <CAPACITOR>C1959</CAPACITOR> and pad 8 (but as the pad of the cap has exploded, and interrupted the trace (i think), does the signal will be there)? I don't have continuity between <RESISTOR>R8131</RESISTOR> and that trace under pad8. 
I tried to screech the trace before the cap, but i don't see that trace, and stopped before damage something, and waited for your reply.

Regarding the <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>, both pads have exploded as shown in the picture. I cant replace the resistance, without first reconstruct the pads (i think) because i don't have where to solder the resistance? Am i wrong? If not, where is the best place to pull those signals?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
It worked like this!
Don't know if it was the best way, but for me it worked.
Thanks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Is a very big trace for <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> near <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pad 8; just look at a clean board.
